title: Public Meeting Law & Oregon Ethics Requirements

sources.label: OSBA
sources.title: Public Meeting Law Training (State Mandate)
sources.summary: Details about the state-mandated public meeting law training that all Oregon elected officials must complete, effective January 1, 2024.

sources.label: OGEC
sources.title: Oregon Government Ethics Commission
sources.summary: The state agency responsible for enforcing ethics laws for public officials, including financial disclosure, conflict of interest, and gift rules.

takeaways: Oregon's Public Meeting Law requires that all meetings of a governing body be open to the public, with limited exceptions.
Since January 1, 2024, all elected officials in Oregon must complete public meeting law training each term.
Public records requests can apply to board members' emails, texts, and social media if they relate to public business.
Violations of public meeting law or ethics requirements can result in voided actions, fines, or removal from office.

knowledgeCheck.question: Public meeting law training is optional for Oregon school board members.
knowledgeCheck.explanation: Since January 1, 2024, public meeting law training is mandatory for all elected officials in Oregon, including school board members. It must be completed each term.

knowledgeCheck.question: A board member's personal text messages about school business are:
options: Potentially subject to public records requests
Only subject to records requests if sent during meetings
Protected unless sent from a district device
knowledgeCheck.explanation: Under Oregon's Public Records Law, communications about public business — including personal texts and emails — may be subject to public records requests regardless of the device used.
